At a meeting of the Board of
Trustees last Wednesday a signal
honor was bestowed upon Mr. B.
FIowell Griswold, '94. He was
elected a trustee to fill the vacancy
left by the late Major R. M. Venable. This comes as a recognition
of the large amount of work, official and unofficial, which Mr.
Griswold has done for the University. The services which he has
rendered University athletics as
graduate adviser to the football
team and now also the baseball
team, are too well known to require
comment. His greatest and best
work he has done, however, as
chairman of the endowment fund
committee. We may well say that
the energy with which Mr. Griswold prosecuted the campaign for
the endowment fund is largely responsible for the success so far met
with. His election as a member of
the Board of Trustees will be hailed
wall delight by undergraduate,
graduate, and alumnus.

Senior Banquet.

J. B. Reeside and Freddie Lee
are entered in the Cross Country
Club's race on Wednesday, February 22.
Dr. J. G. Grose, of Grace M. E.
Church, and Mr. T. W. Poilett, of
Pennsylvania State College, will
be the principal speakers at the Y.
M. C. A. meetings next week.
A bill has been introduced into
the legislature of -Wisconsin for
raising the tax for the support of
the State university from twosevenths Of a mill to three-eighths of
a mill. This will increase the income of the university by from
$750,000 to $1,0b0,000.

The senior banquet will be given
at the New . Howard Hotel on
Thursday, February 23. The toastmaster is H. H. Musser. The following toasts will be responded to:
The Class—H. B. Hering.
Athletics—E. C. Stollenwerck.
The University—R. S. McCabe.
Class Spirit—Harry Linden.
The Cold, Cold World—W. Berry
Waters.
Reunions—J. Reaney Wolfe.
The banquet committee, consisting of Ben Tappan, chairman, H.
C. Burgan, and J. R. Wolfe, announces that a splendid menu has
been prepared. .Everything has
been splendidly arranged and, rain
or shine, it will be the finest banquet
ever held at Hopkins.

20, 1911

FAMOUS MEN COMING

DANIEL CO1T GILMAN
The Educational Pioneer, Scholar and
Man—Founder of the Johns
Hopkins University.

The Turnbull and Schouler Lectures
Will Be Given in March and
April, Respectively.

History, according to Carlyle, is
the essence of innumerable biographies, but rarely do we find, even
for a brief period, that the history
of a nation, a movement, or an
institution consists of one biography. Such, however, is the case
with the beginnings of real university education in the United
States and the early years of the
Johns Hopkins University, the 35th
anniversary of which will be appropriately celebrated on Wednesday..
The whole life of Dr. Daniel Coit
Gilman was a succession of beneficent activities, and his readiness to
further every worthy cause, his skill
in organizing the scattered forces for
good that go to waste in every community, his happy gift of presenting and commending causes which
he advocated, his uniform kindliness and courtesy, his cordial response to every call for help, and
his generosity, which did not wait
for a call. All these things made
him a leader, a benefactor and a
friend.
The authorized biography' of this
remarkable man has just been published. It is by Dr. Fabian Franklin, a colleague and friend of President Gilman, and treats in a symof the many activipathetic way
pioneer among
this
ties which
American educators had.
But although the services of Dr.
Gilman were many, his supreme
work was the founding of the Johns
Hopkins University. For a quarter
of a century he was the chief factor
in the growth of this new educational venture. It was he who first
in this country established what was
a true university, and thus gave
Baltimore what was, and still is,
a unique place in the history of
education.
Over one-third of Dr. Franklin's
biography is given up to "The Beginnings of Johns Hopkins University" and "Presidency of Johns
Hopkins." Here we are given the
whole history of the Johns Hopkins
University during the presidency of
Dr. Gilman and are made familiar
with this new idea of introducing
German methods in higher education, and, in fact, revolutionizing

The Honorable Maurice Francis
Egan, United States Ambassador to
Denmark, will be the Turnbull
lecturer this year. Dr. Egan will
deliver eight lectures during the last
two weeks of March on the subject "Hymnology." The trustees of
the Turnbull lecture fund think they
are very fortunate in securing Dr.
Egan as the lecturer.
Dr. Egan is one of the best
known men in the diplomatic service. He was born in Philadelphia
on May 4, 1882. He took a Bachelor of Arts degree from La Salle
College in 1873. Later, in 1878,
he took his A. M. degree at Notre
Dame. In 1879 he received the
honorary degree LL. D. from
Georgetown, and in 1891 the J. U.
D. (Juris Uterque Doctor) from
Ottawa Unversity. He received his
degree of Doctor of Philosophy
from Villanova in 1907.
After receiving his A: B. degree,
Dr. Egan acted for some time as
the editor of several magazines. In
1888 he was appointed Professor of
English Literature in the Notre
Dame University. This position he
held until 1895, when he was elected
Professor of English Language and

university education in the United
States. We are told how the
trustees unanimously agreed that
the new institution should be devoted to interests other than collegiate ones, and how Dr. Gilman
set about getting a faculty.
The spirit with which Dr. Gilman undertook the work is shown
in numerous letters which passed
between him and the trustees just
after his selection as president,
come of them coming from all parts
of Europe where he was traveling,
conferring with educational experts
and studying foreign methods. The
selection of the members of the faculty—young men of promise, rather
than tried,experienced scholars—the
makeshift accommodations which
were provided for the instructors,
and the arrangement of the courses
for the first few years are all clearly
told of by Dr. Franklin.
For just twenty-five years Dr.
Gilman served as president. Then
in 1901 he resigned from active
connection with the University.
For a quarter of a century he had
been the chief factor in its administration. There was always harmony
in the faculty, and this harmony

contributed to make Hopkins what
it is today.
It is given only to a few to realize
all that Dr. Gilman really did. The
conception of a university in his
mind had become a reality and this
conception has been realized in at
least half a dozen universities of
the country. His insight into the
conditions of American intellectual
life, and the mastery with which
he seized the opportunity of making
a new departure which has determined the fortunes of all American universities, make him stand
alone, a majestic figure in the
history of education.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
The same difficulties that confronted the Hullabaloo boards •of
the classes of 1911 and of 1912
confront the present joint board.
Although the cost of financing the
book will exceed the cost of those
issued by single classes, because of
the increased number of photographs and larger subject matter,
nevertheless, no well defined and
safe plans have been advanced.
The book was not issued by the
class of 1911, because that class
could not raise the money, nor were
the prospects for raising the money
any brighter when the two classes
co-operated. Furthermore,the present board is handicapped by a late
'start. I was told by a member of the
board only last week that it would
he impossible to issue the book until
some time after the close of the
University, thus causing the loss of
part of the income from the sale of
books and, to a great extent, removing the probability of the payment of back dues by the members
of the classes. It is, then, perfectly
evident that, under the present conditions, the publication of the book
would be disastrous. Any objection that may. exist to abandoning
the publication of the Hullabaloo
may be answered by the fact that
the lapse need only be temporary,
and that the publication of the book
can be assumed by the lower classes,
which, with the advantage of an
early start and concrete plans for
financing the book, will be more
capable of publishing it.
Respectfully,

To the Editor of

Literature in the Catholic University of America, at Washington.
From 1895 to 1907 Dr. Egan occupied this position, writing books
and essays. In 1907' he resigned
his professorship to accept the position of Envoy Extraordinary and
Minister Plenipotentiary to Denmark, which was offered him by
President Roosevelt. This position
he still holds.
All through his years of teaching
and study, Dr. Egan was writing
essays and books. He also was
editor of several well-khown publications. Some of his best known
books are: "Modern Novelists,"
"Lectures on English Literature,"
"The Chatelaine and the Rose,"
"The Ghost in' Hamlet, and Other
Essays on Comparative Literature,"
and "Selections from the Prose and
Poetical Works of Cardinal Newman." As an editor, Dr. Egan contributed , to the publication. of
"World's Best Literature," and
"Encyclopedia of Irish Literature."

The Schouler lecturer will be
Dr. John Bassett Moore, of Columbia University. The lectures
will be delivered on April 20, 21, 26,
and 27, and will be on the "Political Activity of James Buchanan."
Dr. Moore is one of the greatest
authorities on international law of
the present day, and has acted as
representative of the United States
on several commissions of international importance. In 1898 he
served as secretary and counsel in
the Spanish-American Peace Conference at Paris. Again, in 1904,
he acted as agent of the United
States before the United States and
Dominion Arbitration Tribunal.
Several times, also, Dr. Moore has
acted as assistant secretary of
State.
Dr. Moore was born in Smyrna,
Del., on December 3, 186o. He
graduated at the University of Virginia in 1880. Since then he has
received the degree of LL. D. from
Columbia, in 1899 ; Delaware College, 1900; and Yale, 1901. After
graduating from the University of
Virginia, Dr. Moore studied law,
and accepted the position of law
clerk in the Department of State,
in 1885. From 1885 to 1891 he
acted as third assistant secretary
of State. In 1891 he was appointed
Professor of International Law
and Diplomacy at Columbia University. In 1893 he was elected to
the Hamilton Fish Professorship,
and has held that position to the
present time. From April until
September, 1898, he served as
assistant secretary of State. In the
same year as secretary and counsel
at the Spanish-American Peace
Conference in Paris, Dr. Moore
showed his abilities as a diplomat.
As a result of his good work here,
in 1904, when the government
wanted a representative for the
Dominion Arbitration Tribunal, Dr.
Moore was the man who was
, picked. In 1898, Dr. Moore published a "History and Digest of
International Arbitration" in six
volumes. A "Digest of International Law" in eight volumes
followed this in 1906. A twelve
volume edition of "The Works of
James Buchanan" was edited by Dr.
Moore in 1908. He is also an editor
of Political Science Quarterly and
the Journal de Droit International
Privec.

Whites Win Contests.

Last Monday the freshman gymnasium contest was brought to a
close. Before the 25-yard dash was
run off the Whites were seven
points ahead, and it looked as
though the Blues might catch
up. However, by the end of the
race the Whites had increased their
lead to ten points. The place winners were: White, Riley, Del Valle,
Wells, Geisel, and Schreiber.
The final event, the relay race,
was hopelessly lost by the Blues.
So, amid triumphant huzzas, the
Whites were proclaimed the victors
in the contest. Each member of
their side gets a medal. Leibensberger gets the prize for making
the highest individual number of
points; Steuart White, second;
Riley, third.

A very exciting event will take
place on Saturday, March 4. There
will be a chess match between the
freshmen and sophomores. The
match will be played with seven
boards. The members of the teams
to represent the classes have not
yet been elected. Ober is to captain the sophomores and Hammond
will lead the freshmen. The match
is to be played off in Levering
Hall at 2.45 P. M.

Prof. H. F. Reid has been appointed by the American Philosophical Society on a committee to
memorialize Congress with a view
to founding a National Earthquake
Laboratory at Washington.

FAMOUS MEN COMING

DANIEL CO1T GILMAN
The Educational Pioneer, Scholar and
Man—Founder of the Johns
Hopkins University.

The Turnbull and Schouler Lectures
Will Be Given in March and
April, Respectively.

History, according to Carlyle, is
the essence of innumerable biographies, but rarely do we find, even
for a brief period, that the history
of a nation, a movement, or an
institution consists of one biography. Such, however, is the case
with the beginnings of real university education in the United
States and the early years of the
Johns Hopkins University, the 35th
anniversary of which will be appropriately celebrated on Wednesday..
The whole life of Dr. Daniel Coit
Gilman was a succession of beneficent activities, and his readiness to
further every worthy cause, his skill
in organizing the scattered forces for
good that go to waste in every community, his happy gift of presenting and commending causes which
he advocated, his uniform kindliness and courtesy, his cordial response to every call for help, and
his generosity, which did not wait
for a call. All these things made
him a leader, a benefactor and a
friend.
The authorized biography' of this
remarkable man has just been published. It is by Dr. Fabian Franklin, a colleague and friend of President Gilman, and treats in a symof the many activipathetic way
pioneer among
this
ties which
American educators had.
But although the services of Dr.
Gilman were many, his supreme
work was the founding of the Johns
Hopkins University. For a quarter
of a century he was the chief factor
in the growth of this new educational venture. It was he who first
in this country established what was
a true university, and thus gave
Baltimore what was, and still is,
a unique place in the history of
education.
Over one-third of Dr. Franklin's
biography is given up to "The Beginnings of Johns Hopkins University" and "Presidency of Johns
Hopkins." Here we are given the
whole history of the Johns Hopkins
University during the presidency of
Dr. Gilman and are made familiar
with this new idea of introducing
German methods in higher education, and, in fact, revolutionizing

The Honorable Maurice Francis
Egan, United States Ambassador to
Denmark, will be the Turnbull
lecturer this year. Dr. Egan will
deliver eight lectures during the last
two weeks of March on the subject "Hymnology." The trustees of
the Turnbull lecture fund think they
are very fortunate in securing Dr.
Egan as the lecturer.
Dr. Egan is one of the best
known men in the diplomatic service. He was born in Philadelphia
on May 4, 1882. He took a Bachelor of Arts degree from La Salle
College in 1873. Later, in 1878,
he took his A. M. degree at Notre
Dame. In 1879 he received the
honorary degree LL. D. from
Georgetown, and in 1891 the J. U.
D. (Juris Uterque Doctor) from
Ottawa Unversity. He received his
degree of Doctor of Philosophy
from Villanova in 1907.
After receiving his A: B. degree,
Dr. Egan acted for some time as
the editor of several magazines. In
1888 he was appointed Professor of
English Literature in the Notre
Dame University. This position he
held until 1895, when he was elected
Professor of English Language and

For just twenty-five years Dr.

in 1901 he resigned from active

THE NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 20, 1911
COMMUNICATIONS
(THE NEWS-LETTER is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length
upon topics of interest in the University
circles. Alumni especially are urged to
make use of this column.)

THE NEWS-LETTER.
The same difficulties that confronted the Hullabaloo boards •of
the classes of 1911 and of 1912
confront the present joint board.
Although the cost of financing the
book will exceed the cost of those
issued by single classes, because of
the increased number of photographs and larger subject matter,
nevertheless, no well defined and
safe plans have been advanced.
The book was not issued by the
class of 1911, because that class
could not raise the money, nor were
the prospects for raising the money
any brighter when the two classes
co-operated. Furthermore,the present board is handicapped by a late
'start. I was told by a member of the
board only last week that it would
he impossible to issue the book until
some time after the close of the
University, thus causing the loss of
part of the income from the sale of
books and, to a great extent, removing the probability of the payment of back dues by the members
of the classes. It is, then, perfectly
evident that, under the present conditions, the publication of the book
would be disastrous. Any objection that may. exist to abandoning
the publication of the Hullabaloo
may be answered by the fact that
the lapse need only be temporary,
and that the publication of the book
can be assumed by the lower classes,
which, with the advantage of an
early start and concrete plans for
financing the book, will be more
capable of publishing it.
Respectfully,

To the Editor of

FAMOUS MEN COMING

Literature in the Catholic University of America, at Washington.
From 1895 to 1907 Dr. Egan occupied this position, writing books
and essays. In 1907' he resigned
his professorship to accept the position of Envoy Extraordinary and
Minister Plenipotentiary to Denmark, which was offered him by
President Roosevelt. This position
he still holds.
All through his years of teaching
and study, Dr. Egan was writing
essays and books. He also was
editor of several well-khown publications. Some of his best known
books are: "Modern Novelists,"
"Lectures on English Literature,"
"The Chatelaine and the Rose,"
"The Ghost in' Hamlet, and Other
Essays on Comparative Literature,"
and "Selections from the Prose and
Poetical Works of Cardinal Newman." As an editor, Dr. Egan contributed , to the publication. of
"World's Best Literature," and
"Encyclopedia of Irish Literature."

The Schouler lecturer will be
Dr. John Bassett Moore, of Columbia University. The lectures
will be delivered on April 20, 21, 26,
and 27, and will be on the "Political Activity of James Buchanan."
Dr. Moore is one of the greatest
authorities on international law of
the present day, and has acted as
representative of the United States
on several commissions of international importance. In 1898 he
served as secretary and counsel in
the Spanish-American Peace Conference at Paris. Again, in 1904,
he acted as agent of the United
States before the United States and
Dominion Arbitration Tribunal.
Several times, also, Dr. Moore has
acted as assistant secretary of
State.
Dr. Moore was born in Smyrna,
Del., on December 3, 186o. He
graduated at the University of Virginia in 1880. Since then he has
received the degree of LL. D. from
Columbia, in 1899 ; Delaware College, 1900; and Yale, 1901. After
graduating from the University of
Virginia, Dr. Moore studied law,
and accepted the position of law
clerk in the Department of State,
in 1885. From 1885 to 1891 he
acted as third assistant secretary
of State. In 1891 he was appointed
Professor of International Law
and Diplomacy at Columbia University. In 1893 he was elected to
the Hamilton Fish Professorship,
and has held that position to the
present time. From April until
September, 1898, he served as
assistant secretary of State. In the
same year as secretary and counsel
at the Spanish-American Peace
Conference in Paris, Dr. Moore
showed his abilities as a diplomat.
As a result of his good work here,
in 1904, when the government
wanted a representative for the
Dominion Arbitration Tribunal, Dr.
Moore was the man who was
, picked. In 1898, Dr. Moore published a "History and Digest of
International Arbitration" in six
volumes. A "Digest of International Law" in eight volumes
followed this in 1906. A twelve
volume edition of "The Works of
James Buchanan" was edited by Dr.
Moore in 1908. He is also an editor
of Political Science Quarterly and
the Journal de Droit International
Privec.

which has for its object, the development of the powers of observation
of its members. Each member of

Whites Win Contests.

Last Monday the freshman gymnasium contest was brought to a
close. Before the 25-yard dash was
run off the Whites were seven
points ahead, and it looked as
though the Blues might catch
up. However, by the end of the
race the Whites had increased their
lead to ten points. The place winners were: White, Riley, Del Valle,
Wells, Geisel, and Schreiber.
The final event, the relay race,
was hopelessly lost by the Blues.
So, amid triumphant huzzas, the
Whites were proclaimed the victors
in the contest. Each member of
their side gets a medal. Leibensberger gets the prize for making
the highest individual number of
points; Steuart White, second;
Riley, third.

A very exciting event will take
place on Saturday, March 4. There
will be a chess match between the
freshmen and sophomores. The
match will be played with seven
boards. The members of the teams
to represent the classes have not
yet been elected. Ober is to captain the sophomores and Hammond
will lead the freshmen. The match
is to be played off in Levering
Hall at 2.45 P. M.

Prof. H. F. Reid has been appointed by the American Philosophical Society on a committee to
memorialize Congress with a view
to founding a National Earthquake
Laboratory at Washington.
